notes: Alabama uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Alabama county codes are not readily available online, but a website from the University of Alabama Office of Archaeological Research is archived on the Wayback Machine. County codes have only the first letter capitalized.

Alaska site numbers are referred to as Alaska Heritage Resources Survey (AHRS) numbers, and consist of a three-letter designation (tri-graph) relating to the USGS quadrangle map on which the cultural resource is located, followed by a unique sequential number for each site within the quadrangle. Geospatial data including the three-letter quad designations are available at https://mrdata.usgs.gov/ak/quadrangles/.

Arizona uses the Arizona State Museum (ASM) Site Numbering and Quadrangle System, which is a five-part designation including the state (AZ), a sequential letter representing the quadrangle (AÐFF), a number representing the quadrangle subdivision (1Ð16), a unique sequential number within that quadrangle subdivision, and a suffix denoting the site numbering authority (e.g., "ASM"). The quadrangle subdivisions are 15 minute quads; however, the ASM provides the numbering system referenced to the names of the 7.5 minute quads, available at https://statemuseum.arizona.edu/crm/document/quad-map-numbers.

Arkansas uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Arkansas county codes are not readily available online, but codes were kindly provided by the Arkansas Archaeological Survey registrar. Questions should be directed to the registrar.

California uses a state-specific three-part site numbering system consisting of the letters "CA", a three letter code county designation, and a unique sequential number within the county. Each site is also assigned a "Primary Number" consisting of the letter "P", a two digit number representing the county, and a sequential six digit number.
Colorado uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Sites within Mesa Verde National Park have their own county designation ("MV"); Mesa Verde is completely within Montezuma County (MT).

Connecticut uses a two-part site numbering system consisting of a sequential number for each town in CT (in alphabetical order), followed by a unique sequential number for each site within the town. Official CT town names and boundaries are available from the US Census Tigris data as the "county subdivisions" dataset. Some sites that were recorded prior to the adoption of this system still have Smithsonian Trinomial designations. Questions should be directed to the Connecticut Office of State Archaeology.

Delaware uses a modified Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system for archaeological sites; in addition to state and county codes, counties are subdivided into "blocks" (designated AÐK), within which sites are assigned sequential numbers with leading zeros. Historical properties use a slightly different numbering system. Delaware counties have single-letter designations. The Delaware State Historic Preservation Office was not willing to provide a geospatial file of the blocks for public use; questions should be directed to the DE SHPO.

Florida uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Florida county codes are not readily available online, but are available as part of the metadata for the archaeological sites GIS data layer, available at https://www.fnai.org/arrow/data/metadata/archaeology.htm.
Georgia uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Georgia county codes are available online at https://archaeology.uga.edu/sites/default/files/documents/codes.pdf.

Hawaii uses a state-specific four-part numbering system consisting of the Smithsonian Trinomial Hawaii state code (50), a unique number for each island, a HI quadrangle number, followed by a unique sequential number for each site within the HI quadrangle. The HI quadrangle system is subtly different from the USGS system, and the quadrangle boundaries are available at https://files.hawaii.gov/dbedt/op/gis/data/usgs_quads_n83.shp.zip.
Idaho uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Idaho county codes are available online at https://history.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/Consulting_With_Idaho_SHPO.pdf.

Illinois uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Illinois county codes are not readily available online, but codes were kindly provided by the Illinois Historic Preservation Office. Questions should be directed to the Illinois Historic Preservation Office.

Indiana uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Indiana county codes are not readily available online, but codes were kindly provided by the Indiana Division of Historic Preservation and Archaeology. Note that some counties are represented by a single letter, and only the first letter of the county abbreviation is capitalized. Questions should be directed to the Indiana state archaeologist.
Iowa uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Iowa county codes are available online at https://archaeology.uiowa.edu/iowa-county-abbreviations-site-designation.
Kansas uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Kansas county codes are available online at https://www.kshs.org/p/kansas-county-abbreviations-for-archeological-trinomials/15769.

Kentucky uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system. Kentucky county codes are not readily available online, but codes were kindly provided by the Kentucky Office of State Archaeology. Note that some counties are represented by three letters, and only the first letter of the county abbreviation is capitalized (except in the case of three-letter codes). Questions should be directed to the Kentucky state archaeologist.

Louisiana uses the Smithsonian Trinomial site numbering system, with parish codes in place of county codes. Louisiana parish codes are available online at https://www.crt.state.la.us/Assets/OCD/hp/standing-structures-survey/SurveyGuidelines(mastecopyed_9_11_14).pdf.

Maine uses a two-part numbering system consisting of an integer quadrangle number roughly corresponding to USGS 15 minute quads, followed by a unique sequential number for each site within the quadrangle. The numbering system is not readily available online, but a depiction of the quadrangle assignments was kindly provided by the Maine Historic Preservation Commission, from which numbers were assigned to 7.5 minute USGS quads and then geospatially unioned into polygons. Questions should be directed to the Maine Historic Preservation Commission senior archaeologist.
